paper_metadata.title: Energy Efficiency in Turning: A Comparative Analysis of Screw Drive and Linear Drive CNC Machine Tools

machine_info.machine_name: DMG CTX 310 eco, CNC CTX 420 Linear

energy_data.power_consumption: Standby, Spindle, and each Axis: See tables for values during operations and idle.
energy_data.measurement_method: Lumel ND 20 logger, 75 A current transformers with a current output 1 A, according to IEC60044-Accuracy Class 3, 0.5 VA, voltage measured directly.

kpi_metrics.efficiency: Compensation can lead to power consumption reductions of 23–30% for screw drives and up to 36–47% for linear drives.
other_kpis: During machining/processing, the tanϕ value fluctuated from level 1.13 to 1.27 for DMG CTX 310 Eco.
For machine tools with linear drives, individual compensation provided for a significant reduction in reactive energy consumption from the level of 8 kVar to the level of almost 2 kVar.
The lathe with linear drives consumed 130% more reactive power during idle operation compared to the lathe with screw drives.

additional_notes: The paper presents a comparative analysis of energy efficiency in turning operations between CNC machine tools equipped with screw drives and linear drives, focusing on active and reactive energy consumption and the potential of reactive power compensation.
